urn:contentItem:5RXP-4M91-DXH2-60PW-00000-00Fed Chairman Says Several Factors are Supporting the Outlook, Fiscal Policy Has Become More Stimulative - Ongoing Job Gains are Boosting Incomes and Confidence - Foreign Growth is on a Firm Trajectory - Overall Financial Conditions Remain Accommodative; Marc Zuckerberg Said "We Have a Responsibility to Protect Your Data and if We Can't Then We Don't Deserve to Serve You" As He Breaks His Silence on the Facebook Data Scandal And Promises That Lessons Will Be Learned Aired 5-6p ET>2018-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:22ZLexisNexisQUEST MEANS BUSINESS5:00 PM ESTShelly Palmer, Diane SwonkNEWSInternational032101cb.k27Fed Chairman Says Several Factors are Supporting the Outlook, Fiscal Policy Has Become More Stimulative - Ongoing Job Gains are Boosting Incomes and Confidence - Foreign Growth is on a Firm Trajectory - Overall Financial Conditions Remain Accommodative; Marc Zuckerberg Said "We Have a Responsibility to Protect Your Data and if We Can't Then We Don't Deserve to Serve You" As He Breaks His Silence on the Facebook Data Scandal And Promises That Lessons Will Be Learned Aired 5-6p ET>Zain Asher, Dylan Byers, Clare Sebastian

Unemployment Was Revised Down, Quite Dramatically by the Feds; Facebook CEO Marc Zuckerberg to Give Exclusive Interview to CNN - Marc Zuckerberg takes responsibility and said we Made Mistakes - Working to Understand What Happened so It Doesn't Happen Again; Ireland's Data Protection Commissioner's Says Companies Like Facebook Need to be Held Accountable; Fed Raises Rates as Always Makes Debut Says U.S. Economic Outlook Has Strengthened; E.U. Tax Rule Changes Could Hit Big Tech Firms like Facebook; Fed Policymakers Concerned about Trade War

[17:00:00] (APPLAUSE)

(CLOSING BELL RINGING ON WALL STREET)

ZAIN ASHER, CNN HOST, QUEST MEANS BUSINESS: All right, that sound marks the end of yet another trading day on Wall Street. Take a look at this, starting point (INAUDIBLE) session, lots of highs and lows, we did actually get Fed announcement today, the Fed will actually be raising interest rates, that has been priced in so the market had been expecting that but we did end the day down, ever so slightly because there are fears that the rate of interest rate hikes could actually be more accelerated than had been expected.

All right, it is Wednesday, March 21st.

"We have a responsibility to protect your data and if we can't then we don't deserve to serve you," Marc Zuckerberg breaks his silence on the Facebook data scandal and he promises that lessons will be learned.

And the market rally says all after Jerome Powell Fed debut, we will have friend of the show Clare Sebastian will be joining us in a few minutes.

And fresh fears about self-driving cars, for the fleet, for the pace of autonomy has slow down.

Hello everyone, I'm Zain Asher and this my friend is QUEST MEANS BUSINESS.

All right, welcome everyone, I am Zain Asher.

Tonight, Marc Zuckerberg has broken his silence on the data scandal that has consumed his company over the past few days. We heard from Zuckerberg the man himself, he admitted that mistakes have been made - mistakes have been made with users' information and he promised, he made several promises that he was going to fix them.

In a statement posted in the last few hours Zuckerberg says that he takes responsibility, the buck stops with him, he takes responsibility for letting user data end up in the hands of Cambridge Analytica. He announced several new measures to tighten up Facebook's data policies including new restrictions on what data third-party companies can store.

Zuckerberg is also due to sit down with CNN's Laurie Segall for an exclusive interview on CNN later tonight, if you're in London that will be 1:00 a.m. your time; he said in his written statement on Facebook, he said, "At the end of the day I am responsible for what happened on our platforms. I know it takes longer to fix all of these issues than we'd like but I promise you we'll work through this and build a better service over the long-term."

Right, so much to discuss here.

Joining me now is CNN Senior Reporter, Dylan Byers and Shelly Palmer, CEO of The Palmer Group so Shelly I want to begin with you since you're right in front of me.

So, I read this statement there were a few things that I myself - I want to get your take on this, that I myself found alarming and a lot of people have mentioned this before.

Number one the fact that third-party apps even had access to data of your friends in the first place, a lot of people would find egregious. Second of all, that Marc Zuckerberg actually knew about this scandal this debacle since 2015, we the users are only just finding out about it now. And third of all that when Cambridge Analytica said, hey, listen we've deleted all the data, Marc Zuckerberg instantly believed them only to find out later that may or may not have been true.

Is this forgivable?

SHELLY PALMER, CEO, THE PALMER GROUP: Well, well, that's a lot of questions that are all kind of well asked - and well - and they should be asked. Let's take them one at a time.

Should you have data available to third parties and should that data include not only your data but the data from your friends?

Whether that's right or wrong in 2014 that was Facebook's policy and they published that policy. We could argue with it that it's a bad idea or a good idea but that was what you agreed to when you click the user license agreement.

Now -

ASHER: I see.

PALMER: - I could morally say to you well, that sounds awful and I can make all kinds of personal comments about what we think in 2018 should have happened in 2014 but in 2014 that was their policy.

And so, Facebook is free. No, it's not. Facebook is nothing like free, you get to use -

ASHER: User information is -

PALMER: - the service because -

ASHER: - the product that is being -

PALMER: - Right.

ASHER: - sold.

PALMER: Your information is what you pay for Facebook with so back then it was not a very well understood business. They were trying to basically serve you the right ad at the right time and to get you engage and they felt that this was a way to do it.

We've really matured over the last four years and certainly through -

ASHER: That's right.

PALMER: - the elections but back in 2014 in a more innocent time that was their policy. It hasn't been their policy for quite some time and so we're talking about data prior to that.

The next question you asked was well Marc Zuckerberg new in 2015, what should he have said?

I can't answer for Marc Zuckerberg but I can tell you that everyone that I know at Facebook, people were very close, now that he is and have said to me in all honesty, 'he's beside himself,' with -

ASHER: I can imagine.

PALMER: - and wants to fix it and with an engineering brain like Zuckerberg has and he is first and foremost an engineer his first inclination is to fix it.

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: Right and I thought his -

ASHER: And he outlined -

PALMER: - statement today.

ASHER: - several ways to do it -

PALMER: He did.

ASHER: - to try and (INAUDIBLE) is what he was trying to say.

PALMER: He actually -

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: - did and what I believe in earnest is the right thing for him to have done is said, "Look, the

buck stops with me." He's taken full responsibility. He knows this is super important.

[17:05:14]

So, you've got a guy who is an engineer at heart who wants to fix things who knows how to forensically look and fix things, knows that it needs to be fixed and has agreed to fix it.

I don't know what more they can actually do at the moment.

We can argue with him if it was a good idea or bad idea over the last few years.

Now the last question you asked was about Cambridge Analytica, how they get a hand - their hands on it - you know, the bad guys, and how they get their hands on it and what went down?

ASHER: And that they told Marc that they deleted it.

PALMER: That they deleted the data and that he believed them.

ASHER: Questionable(ph).

PALMER: I think Facebook is going to have to answer for that flat out. I think -

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: - someone's going to have to go to Facebook and say, "Wait, did they give you an affidavit did they - or like how, do you, know they deleted this data," I think that is a reasonable question that any reasonable person would ask and I think Facebook owes everyone an answer about that.

ASHER: Shelly standby, let me bring in Dylan Byers into the conversation.

So, you know, Dylan you know, we waited four days for this statement from Marc Zuckerberg. Apparently, he wanted to wait so that he could give a really detailed, thoughtful, response, certainly understandable, was this particular statement worth the wait do you think?

DYLAN BYERS, CNN MONEY, SENIOR MEDIA REPORTER & AUTHOR, "PACIFIC" NEWSLETTER: Well you know, first of all everything that Shelly said is absolutely right and certainly it lines up with all of our reporting.

Look being the CEO of a company requires more than just sort of you know, going into hiding for four days and working on improving the product and then coming out. There's - you also have to be aware of the sort of public conversation and the narrative that's happening out there.

There is a lot of time for a very critical narrative about Facebook to develop and fester over the course certainly of Monday and Tuesday and today before Marc Zuckerberg came out with this statement.

You ask is it - is it enough, was it worth the wait?

I don't know. As - look all - everything - almost everything that happened in this scandal happened above board, it happened in line with Facebook policy. Users do go online and they do - or at least they did in the past agreed to share this data and to have - and to have your data shared if you were a friend of somebody who shared their data. All that is true.

But the problem is, is that I think Americans especially have been woefully naive about how much data they are sharing and what issues like this and issues like Facebook's role in Russian meddling in the 2016 campaign highlight is that Facebook's reach, of our data, the way that they follow us around whenever we are in line even when we're not on Facebook on platforms, that Facebook really has a lot of this data and that this data can always be exploited, can always be manipulated by third parties and that no matter what Facebook does, there is always the possibility of a violation like this.

They can monitor it better but they can never wholly prevent it and so the real question here -

ASHER: Yes.

Byer: - is, are people going to look and re-think about whether or not they want to be giving their data to a platform that they haven't been able to trust in the past, that certainly like you said took years to address this problem and are they - are they willing to continue trusting that platform when they know again that they can't wholly prevent this problem from happening again.

I'm not so sure that the case on the other hand, we're talking about over 2 billion users around the world that's a lot of (INAUDIBLE), it's you know, the - Facebook could see user declines of 2 or 3 percent and really ultimately it wouldn't hurt the bottom-line.

ASHER: OK. Fair enough.

But in terms of user responsibilities both of you brought up a very interesting point about user responsibilities because what is our responsibility, yes of course, we clicked "Yes," to the terms and condition but if you talk to ordinary people who are on Facebook, many of whom are teenagers, many of whom are very young, the privacy policy is - of Facebook are so cumbersome and so difficult to understand.

A lot of people think Shelly that that is done by design what are your thoughts?

PALMER: It - it's neither done by design or not by design. We give up our privacy for the quality of our enjoyment of the intranet (ph). If you want to see relevant ads and relevant content, if you want to dynamically create an environment for you that is most - that you are most likely to want to engage with, then you have to give up your data in order for a computer, basically an algorithm to give you what you want.

If you want to see plain-vanilla ads and plain-vanilla content it will become an incredibly emotionally unsatisfying experience so we'll say oh that's - I could deal with that. No, you really couldn't. You'd find this to be an incredibly cumbersome environment.

Let's - let's break this down. We live in - we're living in a world where we create data everywhere, everything we do we create data points. When you say Facebook knows something about me, no, they don't. Facebook has a data set and if you actually data set, can I find Zain - or - people like Zain who are likely to buy this thing at this day, if you ask the right question it will give you back an answer. And that's how Facebook uses Facebook and that's how the data is rightly used.

What we are talking about is when data is used improperly or - by a bad actor.

Now Robert Mueller III, has a new job but in his old job as Director of the FBI, he had a great quote [17:05:16] my most favorite quote on the subject -

ASHER: What's that?

PALMER: - "There's only two kinds of companies in the world, companies that have been hacked and companies that do not know they have been hacked."

ASHER: True (ph).

PALMER: And in this case, it wasn't even a hack, this was inside a policy because we were too young -

ASHER: It's completely above-board as -

PALMER: - we were -

ASHER: - you said.

PALMER: - That's right. We were too young as a society and too young in business to understand the ramifications of this much data.

So now we're coming to a world where we're living in a data-driven society and none of us - none of us can say we understand fully what the dangers are.

It might be worth a stronger look.

ASHER: (INAUDIBLE) -.

BYERS: Zain, I do want to go back - I would -

ASHER: - (INAUDIBLE) -

BYERS: - like to go back to your question. There's - there's - you know, Shelly, there's something really important there which is a question of you know, we agreed to these user agreements and they're really long and they're really cumbersome and ultimately, it's on us for just scrolling to the bottom and clicking, "OK," and actually -

ASHER: Nobody reads -

BYERS: - thinking about -

ASHER: - those fully.

BYERS: - the data we're given up but there is regulation coming in the European Union, at the end of May that is going to make this a much clearer choice for Facebook users and other social media users in the European Union.

You're going to have clear options to say would you like to share your data and are you OK with that data being used for marketing purposes. You're also going to have the opportunity to take back your data and give it to another company.

That sort of regulation - look I don't have a great deal of faith in the - in the U.S. Congress' ability to impose that kind of regulation but if that works in Europe and if Europeans like that that could be an interesting test case for tech regulation here in the United States later down the line.

ASHER: That is certainly a valid point. A lot of people are saying that regulators have been at least five steps behind technology companies -

BYERS: They're always going to be.

ASHER: - but guys I'm running out of time, I'm so sorry.

Dylan Byers, thank you so much.

I want to remind our viewers that you can actually catch more from Dylan Byers in terms of his newsletter, "PACIFIC" that is available every single day.

And Marc Zuckerberg is actually going to give an exclusive interview to CNN's Laurie Segall in just a few hours from now, you can watch that on "ANDERSON COOPER 360" at - which airs at 1:00 a.m. if you're in London, that is local time, and it will be replayed throughout the day on Thursday as well.

After British and E.U. regulators told me they still want answers from Facebook, now Ireland's Data Protection Commissioner says she needs them to step up, earlier Helen Dixon told me companies like Facebook need to be held accountable.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

HELEN DIXON, IRISH DATA PROTECTION COMMISSIONER: I suppose what the events of the last weekend have highlighted for us is this, even where Facebook have terms and policies in place for app developers it doesn't necessarily give us the assurance that those app developers are abiding by the policies that Facebook have set and that Facebook is active in terms of overseeing that there is no leakage of personal data and the conditions such as the prohibition on sending on data to further third parties is being adhered to by app developers.

So, I suppose what we want to see changed and what we want to oversee with Facebook now and what we're demanding answers from Facebook in relation to is first of all what preclearance and what preauthorization do they do before permitting app developers onto their platform.

And secondly once those app developers are operatives and have apps collecting personal data, what kind of follow-up and active oversight steps does Facebook take to give us all reassurance that the type of issue that appears to have occurred in relation to Cambridge Analytica won't happen again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASHER: I'm joined now by Shelly Palmer again, thank you for sticking around so you know, what she's talking about is really this inherent trust of third-party apps just doesn't seem to fly.

I know that Marc Zuckerberg actually addressed in his post that he's going to make sure that third-party companies are going to agree to audits and if they don't agree to audits then they won't be allowed to work with Facebook.

Fair enough but are regulators also to blame somewhat as well because as you and I and Dylan were just talking about, regulators seem to be two, three, four, steps behind these big tech firms?

PALMER: First of all, let's break that down a little bit. What you need data for if you're a third-party app developer and what you should be entitled to, how is it that your app actually works and what do you really need.

Facebook does kind of go a little bit into that, they do and I think they've been - in their minds pretty good about looking at how you use data that you would take in from an app.

If they get too crazy in regulation, if - and I'm saying this as politely as I can, regulators are going to be using a blunt-force instrument on a very delicate situation because not all data that you use, that you give up to somebody is going to hurt anyone; it may really help you enjoy the app that - or get more use out of the app.

Ways, for example, if you don't tell it where you're going and it doesn't keep a record of how you like to travel and where you're going back-and- forth to work then it can't possibly ever learn enough about what you're doing, it will just need - time - just start from the beginning.

[17:05:15]

So, as we get into a world where we're using statistical Machine Learning and Neural Networks and Augmented and Artificial Intelligence to analyze data for things that you do to make your lives better, if we don't give the data to the apps -

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: - can help us -

ASHER: Right.

PALMER: - and so we're just -

ASHER: You have to strike the right balance though.

PALMER: - That's exactly right. And so, what we're hoping for and I'm saying that with all of my heart is that regulators don't have a knee-jerk reaction and go, "Well they've done something bad therefore we must regulate this," to the point where you know, it's so strict you can't actually get the good actors to benefit.

ASHER: Right.

PALMER: There is clearly a problem but Facebook has said they understand there is a problem -

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: - now the question is, are - do people trust them well enough -

ASHER: Hm.

PALMER: - to give them a chance to fix it.

ASHER: We shall see.

All right, Shelly stick around, again.

PALMER: OK.

ASHER: We have another tech story because gosh, it - when it -

PALMER: (INAUDIBLE).

ASHER: - rains it pours, there is more bad news for Facebook and this time it's coming from the - Europe specifically, the E.U. is proposing sweeping tax changes that could cause tech firms like Facebook and Google over 6 billion, with a B, dollars per year. The new digital tax would force companies to pay a levy based on where they make money rather than where the companies' headquarters are actually located.

So, Shelly this is about - for the Europeans this is about basically leveling the playing field and sort of closing the legal loopholes that have existed for several years.

What will it mean financially for these - for these tech companies?

PALMER: The tech companies pay about 10 percent tax in Europe right now and normal businesses pay roughly, 22, 23, 24, percent tax and so the European regulators and the lawmakers are looking at that and saying what - why and how, how does this work, how are they paying less tax and the reason they've determined that they're paying less tax is the way that they are taxed by where their headquarters are versus where they are doing business throughout the 28 countries of the E.U.

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: And so, the proposal is that they're going to tax businesses where the business is done at the point of the consumers' interaction with the business.

I think it's misguided but that's just me personally. I think they're going to have a very high bar. They're going to have to give a lot of buy- in, certainly there are small 'Dutches' (ph) and small countries like Estonia that are really benefiting from the way the tax laws are set up right now and then there's the rest of the E.U. who are - have different feelings about how the tax law should be.

They are looking right at tech companies because they are the easiest ones to look at although they claim in Europe that it's not just about tech.

ASHER: Yes.

PALMER: I have also heard that it has nothing to do with the new tariffs that were proposed here in the United States. On the other hand, I think, wink, wink, everybody thinks that they are heavily related to this trade war that's about to start because taxation is a way to sort of fight a battle in that war.

And so, we've got a bunch of moving parts here -

And as a result, we continue to see significant growth in our relationships with the Chinese consumer. And I think the brand is very strong in China. We just opened a Starbucks reserve glossary in Shanghai, you know, a 30,000 square foot, the largest Starbucks in the world.

And the number of customers that we are serving, not only in that store, but in our stores in China just continues to grow.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ASHER: All right, my friends, that is QUEST MEANS BUSINESS, I'm Zain Asher in New York, news continues right here.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WJB-3FT1-JB20-G14X-00000-00Fed Chief Powell's Comments Affirm Expectations for Rate Cut; Hurricane Watches Issued for Coastal Louisiana; President Trump Set to Hose Social Media Summit at White House; President Trump Save Legislation May Lead To Completion For The Big Tech; Fed Chief Powell's Comments Affirm Expectations For Rate Cut; Ocasio-Cortez Questions Powell On Unemployment And Inflation; California PG&E Safety In Question; Gatorade Debuts Bolt 24 Sports Drink Aimed At 24/7 Hydration2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:22ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTSteve Forbes, John Meyer, Charles Plosser, Brett O'BrienNEWSFinancial071101cb.231Fed Chief Powell's Comments Affirm Expectations for Rate Cut; Hurricane Watches Issued for Coastal Louisiana; President Trump Set to Hose Social Media Summit at White House; President Trump Save Legislation May Lead To Completion For The Big Tech; Fed Chief Powell's Comments Affirm Expectations For Rate Cut; Ocasio-Cortez Questions Powell On Unemployment And Inflation; California PG&E Safety In Question; Gatorade Debuts Bolt 24 Sports Drink Aimed At 24/7 HydrationMaria Bartiromo, James Freeman, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Hey there, ladies, good morning to you. Happy Thursday, everybody, thanks for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, July 11th, your top stories right now, just before 6:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Federal Reserve chairman, Jay Powell, driving global markets higher this morning, and late yesterday, futures pointing to more gains after Powell signaled a rate maybe on the way, the Dow, the S&P and the NASDAQ hitting new intraday highs yesterday, after Powell spoke, only the NASDAQ managed to end the day at a new record high.

Escalating tensions with Iran, Iranian gun boats tied to -- tried to seize a British oil tanker in the Strait of Hormuz, but the attempt thwarted after a British warship intervened. We've got the very latest.

And severe storms hitting the Gulf of Mexico, a state of emergency declared in Louisiana, as oil rigs are evacuated and New Orleans is hit with massive flooding, we've got the forecast.

Then, Bitcoin, plunging this morning, the cryptocurrency takes a hit after Fed chair Powell expresses concern about Facebook's new offering, MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

All right, we've got a big program this morning. Coming up, Philadelphia Federal Reserve president, Charles Plosser, in the studio this morning, undersecretary -- former Under Secretary of State for Economic Growth, Energy and the Environment, Bob Hormats, joining us this morning, along with Tennessee senator Senate Judiciary Committee and Senate Armed Services Committee member, Marsha Blackburn.

Plus, "THE FIVE" co-host Juan Williams, weighing in as well, don't miss a moment of it. Big three hours coming up, right now.

Joining the conversation this morning, FOX Business Network's Dagen McDowell, the Wall Street Journal's assistant editorial page editor, James Freeman, and Forbes Media chairman, former Republican presidential candidate, Steve Forbes, great to see everybody this morning.

STEVE FORBES, CHAIRMAN, FORBES MEDIA: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Yes, great to see you.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Yes, Steve and I jumped into each other at the McDonald's on 6th Avenue, so we're fueled up with the breakfast of champions. We're ready to go.

BARTIROMO: Is that right?

FREEMAN: It's going to be a big morning.

FORBES: Make Maria great again --

BARTIROMO: All right, good. OK.

FORBES: -- even greater.

FREEMAN: We declined the healthy options in the green room.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. It's hilarious.

FORBES: You don't go to McDonald's for a -- go to a fat farm.

BARTIROMO: I would've expected you to go to 7-Eleven on this slopey day, by the way, 7/11. Anyway, markets this morning are higher, we had the Powell conversation yesterday and, of course, the testimony hit markets on the upside, and we got that optimism once again this morning, the chairman, Jay Powell's comments about the rate cuts and the backdrop for the economy.

The Central Bank sounded dovish on future rate cuts, citing global and domestic economic conditions, watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEROME POWELL, CHAIRMAN, FEDERAL RESERVE: We look at a broad range of data, so let's start with a broad where, I think, since the June meeting and for a period before that, the data have continued to disappoint. Let's go to trade, we have agreed to begin discussions again with China, well, that's a constructive step. It doesn't remove the uncertainty that we see as overall, weighing on the outlook.

So, I would say that the bottom line for me, is that the uncertainties around global growth and trade continue to weigh on the outlook, in addition, inflation continues to be muted and those things are still in place.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: He talked about cross currents weighing on the outlook as well, Steve, what did you think of that yesterday?

FORBES: Well, he certainly has learned his lesson from President Trump, although he never admit it, and I think, too, though, one of the things that did not get much attention yesterday was he's opened the first shot against Judy Shelton. He planted question on the gold standard, they don't want her on the Federal Reserve board.

They're going to try to do to her what they did to Stephen Moore and Herman Cain. And so, I think you're going to see some fireworks there. The empire does not want dissidents on its board.

BARTIROMO: Wow, so you -- so that was all planned in terms of the response making -- putting the stake in the ground on that.

FORBES: As they use to say, there are no coincidences, comrade.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I guess so.

FREEMAN: Yes, I want Judy Shelton on the Fed.

FORBES: So do I.

FREEMAN: I think Americans should want her on the Fed. And I think she's going to prove a more formidable dissident than maybe some of the others with due respect to her friends.

FORBES: She knows how to ask the right questions.

FREEMAN: Yes.

FORBES: And knows she's got all the economic credentials, so they can't say, oh, you don't have PhD, she does, and that's what they fear, an informed critic.

BARTIROMO: But they don't want -- yes, they don't want dissidents.

FORBES: You bet.

FREEMAN: And as you said, very dovish, and we are seeing that in the minutes too. This is a group that kind of likes inflation. It's weird when you, sort of, study the history of monetary policy to see how much -- I don't want to say obsessed with making sure we have inflation, I don't know why from a saver consumer point of view, you want to ensure that you have inflation.

FORBES: Yes. Well, two percent inflation, making $60,000 a year that means an extra $1,200 you have to spend extra, that's supposed to stimulate the economy, not.

BARTIROMO: Wow.

FORBES: And they still worship this idea that prosperity causes inflation, a little Phillips curve (INAUDIBLE) low unemployment, you have to have high inflation. We have low inflation, low unemployment, but at the Fed, they ignore reality.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: We're finally getting wages - -

FORBES: obsolete theories.

MCDOWELL: We're finally getting wages growing north of three percent for the first time in this expansion under the Trump administration, and they want to foul it up.

FORBES: And those wage increases are coming especially for low-income workers, nonsupervisory workers, the people you want to have moving up.

MCDOWELL: Greg Ip has a column in the Wall Street Journal about that very thing today. The -- a record expansion surprise winners are the low- skilled workers in this country. But it was surprising what happened, there was no chance for half-point cut before the testimony yesterday, now there is a 29 percent chance based on the future's market of a half point rate cut in July.

A half point rate cut in July, frankly, would signal that there are much bigger weaknesses on the horizon because that's exactly what the Fed did in 2001 and 2007, it was when they started, they initiated half-point cuts rather than quarter point cuts when there was clear signs of weakness in the economy, so I'd be careful what you wish for.

BARTIROMO: Well, he did say that manufacturing and housing are the two weak spots right now, and then there was the cross currents of uncertainty over trade. But when you look at the economy today, I mean, today, things look pretty good, I mean, you've got these uncertainties on the horizon, but 50 basis points seems a little harsh even if it's just an uncertainty.

FORBES: I think they'll go for 25, they are very shy --

BARTIROMO: In July?

FORBES: Yes, 25 basis points, not 50.

FREEMAN: I don't see the case for any cutting.

BARTIROMO: I don't know either.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: There is one.

FREEMAN: You are concerned about these trade negotiations, capital expenditures not what we would like them to be, but that was a great jobs report. He basically dismissed it yesterday. And you look at where the Federal funds rate is versus inflation, still historically very low.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FREEMAN: Right? I don't hear businesses saying we need a quarter point, lower interest rate, and then we'll borrow (INAUDIBLE) about trade.

MCDOWELL: We look back to '95 and '98, where the Fed was doing -- initiated quarter point cuts as the so-called insurance policy against a recession, and that did seem to work, '98 was the Russian debt -- the Russian debt crisis, long-term capital management collapsed and we also had the impeachment of President Bill Clinton and the star report coming out all of the same time.

And the Fed did prevent a recession, quite frankly, that you -- that they cut rates, boo with the market, boo with asset prices and we didn't get a recession until 2000.

BARTIROMO: We should --

FORBES: My monetary --

MCDOWELL: 2001

FORBES: -- policy is not going to be a substitute for getting these trade disputes out of the way.

FREEMAN: Right.

MCDOWELL: That's --

BARTIROMO: Good point. And that's where the cross currency of the trade come in. Let's talk Middle East tensions for a minute, because Iranian ships attempted to block a U.K. tanker in the Strait of Hormuz, only to be turned around by a British warship.

This area has been rocked recently by a string of confrontations, including the downing of an American drone by Iran and attacks on oil vessels, which the U.S. is blamed on the Islamic Republic. This is in the latest escalation, James, your reaction?

FREEMAN: Yes, it's still a wait-and-see in terms of how Iran is really going to react to the president ordering and then rescinding the retaliatory attack, this was another, I don't know if you want to call it, shot across the bow, threatening but then retreating when the U.K. warship was there, but probably does emphasize the need for those ships to be there.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about Nancy Pelosi, taking on her own caucus, for a second, the House speaker in a war of words with new congressional members. Freshman congresswoman, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, sounds off on the spat, telling the Washington Post this, but the persistent singling out. It got to a point where it was just outright disrespectful, the explicit singling out of newly elected women of color.

FORBES: Well --

BARTIROMO: This comment is basically -- AOC is calling Nancy Pelosi a racist.

MCDOWELL: Welcome to our world, welcome to -- if you criticize any individual who's a liberal, who's a left-wing socialist liberal on their ideas, on them, saying something that you find repugnant or offensive, this is what happens, to shut you down and shut you up. They call you a racist and a bigot. And she's trying to pull the same thing with the leader of the Speaker of the House.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable.

MCDOWELL: Who's been around a lot longer than you have, long before social media, and she knows how to govern.

FORBES: And when you have to play that card, it shows she's being isolated, AOC, because Pelosi wouldn't attack her and her colleagues like that if she wasn't worried about the 20 to 30 moderate Democrats who are in seats that they could lose in 2020. She wants to keep the house rather than apiece the extremist in her party.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: Using your gender, using your ethnicity, using your gender, as a crutch that you lean on, and then they will turn around and whack you with it --

BARTIROMO: It's pretty incredible.

MCDOWELL: -- rather than standing on ideas, rather than standing by what you say, if somebody finds it offensive, then defend it. They can't.

FORBES: She can't.

BARTIROMO: Don't forget, she's trying to get people to replace all of the people who have been in there for so long. I mean, AOC is trying to primary a lot of these guys and gals out.

FREEMAN: Yes. And Nancy Pelosi may someday regret signing on with the resistance in early 2017. But I think your social media point is right on here, because it's not that they have a difference of opinion, and AOC is further to the left, Nancy Pelosi is saying, I don't think all your Twitter followers add up too much. I don't think you actually represent many people in the country.

BARTIROM: Right.

FREEMAN: She's questioning the authority of AOC, and I think that's what is driving AOC, crazy, here.

MCDOWELL: Speaker Pelosi did the right thing in getting the Democrats together and voting for the $4.6 billion in humanitarian aid, the majority of that going to Health and Human Services to take care of children, who didn't vote for it? Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, she didn't vote for it the first time, or the second time, the senate bill.

Instead, she goes down to the border and creates a social media scene to benefit one person, not the women, not the children, but herself. And if you're Nancy Pelosi, the Speaker of the House, the leader of the Democrats in Washington, in the House of Representatives, you would be, you know what, too.

BARTIROMO: Then she came out with misinformation, I mean, that was --

FORBES: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- all misinformation, telling people that they were telling migrants to drink water from the toilet bowl, absolutely not true.

FORBES: No. And I think there's a classic case where Pelosi let AOC hang herself, do at her own words, and public opinion is going on the side of the president and the whole border issue.

But that raises what's going to happen next week with these ICE raids, not going after MS-13 gang members, or go after them, but when you have the pictures of the women and children being deported, that's going to be a tough one.

BARTIROMO: Yes. All right, we'll take a quick break. When we come back, Lockheed Martin stayed in Pennsylvania, another victory for the president. We're going to talk about that. Coming up, though, a tropical storm, building strength in the Gulf of Mexico, parts of Louisiana, already dealing with widespread flooding, the latest developments, coming up.

And then Bitcoin is under pressure this morning, the digital coin takes a hit after the Fed Chairman Jay Powell warns Congress about the cryptocurrency coming out of Facebook, his remarks, straight ahead. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Hurricane watches posted for parts of Louisiana, ahead of a tropical storm, Cheryl Casone with the details now in headlines, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. Louisiana is under a state of emergency as severe flooding stuns New Orleans already, flash flooding turned streets into rivers, some residents had to cut across town in their kayaks.

This is Tropical Storm Barry, which has gained strength over the Gulf of Mexico. Forecasters are warning now that heavy downpours are still going to be a threat over the next several days.

Oil industry is bracing for what's expected to be the first hurricane of the season (INAUDIBLE) about a third of production in the Gulf. And as you can see, oil is up about half a percent right now, $60.74 a barrel, right now, WTI.

Well, Labor secretary Alex Acosta is defending how he handled convicted pedophile, Jeffrey Epstein's sex-trafficking case in 2018. Acosta blamed the Palm Beach State Attorney's Office and he said it was ready to let Epstein walk free.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ALEX ACOSTA, SECRETARY OF LABOR, UNITED STATES: Facts are important, and facts are being overlooked. What is the value of a secured guilty plea with registration versus rolling the dice?

And I know that in 2019, looking back on 2008, things may look different, but this was the judgment of prosecutors with dozens of years of experience. In our part, we were trying to do the right thing for these victims.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: And there's more, the NYPD reportedly did not check in with Epstein once -- one time at all since he was labeled a level three sex offender back in 2011. Epstein should have reported to the police 34 times. This is according to a report this morning in the New York post.

All right, Deutsche Bank is under investigation by the Justice Department, officials are looking into whether the bank violated anti-money laundering laws when it worked for Malaysian Development Fund, 1MDB.

The fund has been at the center of a fraud scandal but the justice department says led to, at least, $4.5 billion being stolen and even led to down fall of the former Malaysian prime minister. There is Deutsche Bank in the premarket, down almost a percent.

Then, there is this, Lockheed Martin is staying in Pennsylvania, the defense giant keeping open a helicopter plant there after President Trump had called for it.

The president tweeted on that news, "I was just informed by Marillyn Hewson, CEO of Lockheed Martin, of her decision to keep the Sikorsky Helicopter Plant in Coatesville, Pennsylvania open and humming. We are very proud of Pennsylvania and the people who work there. Thank you to Lockheed Martin, one of the USA's truly great companies.

So, more jobs are staying in the U.S., Maria.

BARTIROMO: All right, Cheryl. Thanks so much, another good job story there. Coming up, Bitcoin is under pressure this morning, the digital coin takes a hit after the Fed chairman warn congress about Facebook's cryptocurrency, we've got his remarks coming up next.

And then, it is raining money, an armored truck spills cash, stopping traffic, police now warning those who cashed in, they want the money back, later this hour, stay with us.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The Federal Reserve would use (INAUDIBLE) some postponement and they're implementing Libra.

POWELL: There are deep, important serious questions across a range of issues here that will need to be addressed. It does have, potentially, systematic scale. And for all the reasons we discussed, it needs a careful look.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Federal Reserve chair, Jay Powell, set for a second day of testimony this morning, on Capitol Hill. Yesterday, he spoke with the House Financial Services Committee, warning congress of the risks from Facebook's planned cryptocurrency, Libra.

Now, Bitcoin prices are down, as a result, joining us right now is technology analyst, managing partner at Starship Capital, John Meyer, and John, it is good to have you on the program this morning, thanks so much for being here.

JOHN MEYER, MANAGING PARTNER, STARSHIP CAPITAL: Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: What's your reaction to, first, the Facebook Libra product, because Bitcoin has been trading on it ever since the announcement?

MEYER: You're right. My reaction to Libra is that, it is really a natural next step. I mean, Bitcoin has been around for about 10 years now. It's seen extreme problems and it's also rightfully so, it's evolved quite a bit since then.

I think Libra is a step beyond Bitcoin, taking Bitcoin's technology, underlying technology block chain and applying it to pretty much most mainstream software you can get, which is now Facebook. And so, what Libra is trying to do is make it extremely easy to basically be able to send the money around the world, to your friends and families with very little fees.

And with very little of the problems that you normally have today in banking, such as the fact that you can only do it on workdays, the fact that you have the substantial fees to transfer money. And so Libra is taking that up a notch and making banking fully digital, the problem is, and what, you know, our government rightfully points out, is that this is a-- it's a very colossal step forward.

It's a big difference from what we have now with traditional banking. And it technically does allow a citizen in the U.S. or a citizen let's say, in Germany, really, anywhere around the world, to go around our traditional banking system.

And I -- and I respect the fact, as a technology analyst, that that does require a careful look on our government's side.

FREEMAN: John, James Freeman here at the Wall Street Journal, that sounds kind of cool in a lot of ways if you can around what could be a highly- regulated expensive traditional banking system, sounds like more choice for consumers.

MEYER: Definitely more choice for consumers and you know, what's beautiful about this is, again, I remind you that even Bitcoin was created on the back of the 2008 financial crisis and it was created for the reason of providing a more safe and fair financial system.

And, you know, Facebook has fixed some of Bitcoin's biggest issues, and actually adding a bit more transparency for, let's say, regulators and transparency for government agencies to actually have some control over this unlike Bitcoin, which is very, very much, I'd say, untouchable, in many ways by regulators.

FORBES: John, Steve Forbes here (INAUDIBLE) one of the big down falls of a Bitcoin are shortcomings, is its volatility, you know, steak one day, dog food the next, and Libra is promising stability, going to tie it to currencies or something not to gold, which they should, but if they get that kind of stability, you could use this as money, this could break the monopoly of governments on money.

And no wonder the Fed is concerned, is this sort of like Uber or BNB, kind of like blast away the old way of doing things?

MEYER: Right. Yes, I think -- I think this really has the potential to be something like that. And what's so interesting about this is that Facebook is absolutely pegging Libra directly to the U.S. dollar, which is fantastic, and that means that you're right, Steve.

The volatility issue of Bitcoin is gone with Libra, and this makes it incredibly easy for you to send money around the world, as a business or as an individual, with very little fees and that in itself could help economies all over the world and it could help some of the more, you know, second and third-world countries who actually struggle with immense inflation.

Because this is a currency that will be pegged to the U.S. dollar that will prevent all of that, and all you need is an internet connection, which, you know, as we know now, is absolutely the top priority in many third-world countries over even, let's say, finding food.

And so that's what's so incredible about this, is it solves some of the biggest issues that actually threaten democracy around the world and that are why I'm a fan of it. However, I still think the U.S. government needs to really know how it's actually working and what the exact repercussions are, which I'm not so confident in, right now.

And so, I think, the fact that they will be taking their time to delve into this, is smart on them, because this will have a huge impact on the U.S. financial system and on the global financial system full stop.

FORBES: But there's no way to predict that in the -- in the future, what the impact it's actually going to be, and you've got this digital wallets which is where handhelds were 35 years ago, which are now just being used for transfer of payments, they could replace the banking system when you look down 5 or 10 years down the road.

BARTIROMO: Do you believe that, Steve?

FORBES: I do. I think this has got enormous potential, and not entirely tongue-in-cheek, I suggested an open letter to Mark Zuckerberg, don't be bashful, why call it the Libra, which is a measurement for the Roman empire and we know what happened to that.

(INAUDIBLE) call it the Mark, the Germans gave up the Mark, so called it after himself, the Mark.

BARTIROMO: I like it. Look, let me switch gears, ask you about the social media summit going on at the White House today, President Trump hosting prominent conservatives today at the White House to talk about how they can stop the suppression of their views on Facebook, Twitter, Google, other platforms. The president told me last month, tech companies may need more regulation, watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Would you rather see competition or do you want to see legislation coming down to actually --

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Well, you may need legislation in order to create competition.

BARTIROMO: Is what technology companies are doing, what they did that to you, is that legal? Are they breaking the law, Mr. President?

TRUMP: Well, I don't know whether or not. But I tell you what, they should be sued.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: They should be sued. Now, I know a number of these guys have testified in front of congress, it should be noted that the White House is not inviting any tech companies to this event today, but you've got a lot of people there that have been shadow banned, that have complained about censorship, what's your reaction, what comes out of this today?

MEYER: You know, I think what comes out of today is a bit of a stronger sense of centralized message on the Trump side of things, especially as it relates to his views towards the social media giants, Twitter and Facebook. And so, I do think it'll give him a bit more of an established presence with his arguments that there is shadow banning happening, that there is some sort of manipulation happening.

However, I do think it'll be extremely important to have the actual tech companies at the table and, you know, maybe they do another summit for that, but that's going to be incredibly important, because there's going to be -- go ahead.

BARTIROMO: No, please finish.

MEYER: Because if there's going to be a disconnect between, you know, the actual problems that Trump is raising and these natural tech companies who believe that they are following, you know, a bit of a standard protocol across all accounts, you know, these issues are still going to be up there.

And so, what I'd like to see is just a reasonable resolution on both sides, where both sides are heard and we can move forward.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MEYER: And not be so stressed about --

BARTIROMO: I was just going to point out that some of these executives have already been to the White House, so you know --

MEYER: Right.

BARTIROMO: -- Jack from Twitter, met with the president, a number of the others, Eric Schmidt, they've testified in front of congress and have also been at the White House as well.

MCDOWELL: There's not going to be -- there's not going to be anybody there today to defend the claims that will be aired.

FORBES: Well, and but though -- but those executives have not followed through on the removing crazy things like going after (INAUDIBLE) University for crying out loud. They're political -- they're -- politically, they're brain dead in terms of they should fix this right away.

BARTIROMO: Yes, I mean, you look at something like a -- like a Twitter. Devin Nunes -- Congressman Nunes, suing Twitter because he keeps getting shadowed in and his posts are taken down.

And meanwhile, AOC, she doesn't -- you know, she says whatever she wants, and her posts don't get taken down.

FORBES: Right.

BARTIROMO: So, this is the argument that Devin Nunes has been --

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: Yes, so the natural opponent's regulation now wanted too. So, consumers, beware, there's a big consensus with big government and big companies to have regulation here.

MCDOWELL: Why doesn't somebody come along and open more and more social media networks? Again, that's the free market work.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: People are upset by the way that they get treated by the -- this oligopoly of social media companies then, bring on the competition.

BARTIROMO: No, you heard what the president just said two weeks ago when he was on this program, we might need legislation to spark competition. I found that interesting.

FORBES: Yes, its --

MCDOWELL: But the --

FORBES: It's a -- it's a warning shot to those companies.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

FORBES: Fix your problem before you get the political fix.

BARTIROMO: Exactly. John, thanks so much. Great conversation. We appreciate you joining us this morning.

MEYER: Live, well, thank you.

BARTIROMO: We will see you soon, sir. Coming up, trade is in focus. U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer expected to meet with Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill today. More on the push to get USMCA passed. It's going to be important.

Then, McDonald's franchise is climbing foul. A burger giant urging to focus on chicken later this hour. All of that ahead, stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Thursday, July 11th. Your top stories right now 6:34 a.m. on the East Coast. Federal Reserve Chairman Jay Powell, driving global markets this morning and they are higher.

As you see, Futures indicating a gain of 45 points on the Dow this morning. Up 17 on the Nasdaq, adding to gains after Powell signaled a rate cut is on the way. The Dow, the S&P, and the Nasdaq getting new intraday highs after the chairman spoke yesterday. The S&P crossing 3,000 before pulling back. Only in the Nasdaq ended the day at an all-time record high up 60 points at 8202 on the Nasdaq.

In Europe this morning, though momentum continues. Gains, well, look at this, the FTSE has just moved into negative territory, down two points actually. The CAC Quarante is up just a fraction and the DAX Index is lower by 40 points. So, you've got some negative performance this morning in Europe.

Checking Asia this morning overnight, markets were higher across the board. Best performer was the Korean Index, KOSPI up better than one percent.

Trade is in focus. U.S. trade representative Robert Lighthizer expected to meet with Democratic leaders on Capitol Hill today, we've got the preview there.

And then, this fast food battle to report. McDonald's franchising is asking for a chicken sandwich to compete with Chick-fil-A.

Plus, the big money grab. An armored truck sprays money across the Georgia highway. Eddie likes that. People jumped out of their cars to scoop up some currency. The incredible video, what police are doing about it now, needless to say, they want the money back.

All those stories coming up, this Thursday morning. But first, our top story this half-an-hour. Jay Powell back in the hot seat this morning on Capitol Hill. The Federal Reserve chairman will speak in front of the Senate today.

Yesterday, he signaled a possible interest rate cut, citing global and domestic economic conditions. Powell weighed in on economic and trade uncertainties and inflation worries. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

POWELL: Many FOMC participants saw that the case for a somewhat more accommodative monetary policy stance had strengthened. Since then, based on incoming data and other developments, it appears that uncertainties around trade tensions and concerns about the strength of the global economy continue to weigh on the U.S. economic outlook. Inflation pressures remain muted.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Joining me right now is the former president of the Philadelphia Federal Reserve president, Charles Plosser. And it is always a pleasure to see you, sir. Thanks so much for joining us.

CHARLES PLOSSER, FORMER PRESIDENT OF PHILADELPHIA FEDERAL RESERVE: Good morning, great to be here.

BARTIROMO: So, your reaction to what we're seeing today in the economy. We know as a backdrop, we're at a 51 year low on unemployment. We've got growth in the first quarter or better than three percent. And yet here we are talking about rate cuts. What's your take?

PLOSSER: Well, I don't find that there's a compelling case for rate cuts at this point. The stock markets, they're at an all-time high. As you said, unemployment's low, inflations low -- you know, what -- what's so bad about where we are?

It's true though, there's a lot of uncertainty out there and that certainly hinges around policies for the most part. Trade policies perhaps and other things that may happen in around the world, slowing in the global economy or Europe and other places.

But you know, monetary policy can't fix those. The Fed cutting rates now is not going to resolve trade uncertainties. It's not going to (INAUDIBLE) resolve policy problems. And --you know, if we end up in a trade war this serious, yes, the economy is going to take a hit. But the Fed can't do anything about that.

BARTIROMO: That's very important --

(CROSSTALK)

PLOSSER: And I'm really -- I'm really concerned that we are expecting the Fed to do things that it really can't do. And you've heard me talk about this before over the years.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely.

PLOSSER: And putting the onus on the Fed to take responsibility for things that it doesn't have much control over.

And I think that's a very bad place for -- and by the way, Jay Powell, in his language about the Fed will act to sustain the recovery. I think that's very bad language. He can't sustain the recovery in the face of some types of shocks. So, I think we -- I think we're just expecting too much and we need to tone it down.

BARTIROMO: So, when he says sustain the recovery, that's all on anticipation. Anticipating that things are going to slow down because of the uncertainties around trade. He said these new crosscurrents have to do with trade uncertainties.

PLOSSER: Right.

BARTIROMO: Is that largely China or are you talking about other countries? I mean, it's --

(CROSSTALK)

PLOSSER: Well, I think certainly China is a big part of this.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PLOSSER: But you know, the president has threatened put -- has threatened to put tariffs on Mexico, more tariffs on Europe. So I mean, I think -- is that --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: So the uncertainty is that where he's going to go next?

PLOSSER: Where is it going to be next?

BARTIROMO: Yes, yes.

PLOSSER: And how is this all going to get played out? And the Fed can't resolve that, it has to react to that. But as you know, you read the newspapers and the headlines and one week a trade agreement is on, the next week a trade agreement is off.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

PLOSSER: The next week there's a new trade -- and the Fed can't deal with that. And it shouldn't be reacting to that kind of volatility in the news about policy.

BARTIROMO: We know that Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the Congresswoman has really been sort of the loudest voice in the room in terms of questioning current policy. Yesterday, she questioned Powell. She's on the Financial Services Committee. She talked about the Phillips curve, unemployment, and inflation.

Listen to this question. I want to see if you know what she's talking about. I was really perplexed. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. ALEXANDRIA OCASIO-CORTEZ (D-NY): I've been seeing lately that economist are increasingly worried that the idea of a Phillips curve that links unemployment and inflation is no longer describing what is happening in today's economy. Have you been considering on that? What are your thoughts on that?

POWELL: Very much that we spend a great deal of time on that. The connection between slack in the economy or the level of unemployment and inflation was very strong if you go back 50 years and it's gotten weaker and weaker and weaker to the point where it's a faint heartbeat that you can hear now.

It's still there, you can see it at state level data and things like that. But I think we really have learned though that the economy can sustain much lower unemployment than we thought without troubling levels of inflation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, this was the Phillips curve. She also talked about decoupling in the economy which is really what I was questioning. It's a different sound bite, but what's your reaction to that?

PLOSSER: Well, I think the Phillips curve is dead, it's been dead for 40 years. And I think the Fed is mistaken in thinking it can base its ability to stabilize the real economy, that is unemployment, by using control of inflation and vice versa.

And I think that's very problematic for the whole idea of Fed policy and monetary policy being a stabilization tool. And if the Phillips curve isn't there, then the Fed needs to find another way to meet its dual mandate.

BARTIROMO: Do you expect the economy to slow down later this year? We're talking about so far, three percent in the first quarter, maybe a little lower for the first half of the year. But we know that the global economy is slowing. Europe is having a hard time generating any growth. Do you think things slow down?

PLOSSER: Right. Well, I think if you look to go back to the forecast for 2019 last fall, 2018 was coming in close to three percent, almost everyone was forecasting something between two and 2-1/2 percent for 2019.

Is that a good number? Probably still is. And by the way, trend, potential growth is less than two or just under two. So, there's still the forecast that we're going to be at or near trend for 2019. And so, I find the notion that you know, there's this panic that we need to react to, troubling. And the fact that last December, when the markets hit a lot of volatility, I think the Fed overreacted.

They sent a signal that they were going to be dovish and cut rates and they doubled down on that over the course of the spring. And now they're in a position where I think to some degree the Fed's probably afraid that if they don't now deliver on the rate cuts, they're going to -- they're going to cause another bout in volatility, and they don't want to do that.

That's the curse of paying too much attention to financial markets when you do monetary policy.

BARTIROMO: Financial markets and maybe the president's criticism.

PLOSSER: Maybe the president's criticisms too.

BARTIROMO: There's -- there is that as well.

PLOSSER: So, getting above that fray and not reacting to short term volatility and short term reactions is a dangerous place for the Fed to be, but that's a failure that they been -- they gotten into over the long -- of all the years.

BARTIROMO: To be clear, we could have prosperity and growth without inflation.

PLOSSER: Of course. Of course.

BARTIROMO: And so, you know, why are we so worried that inflation is not meeting the target?

PLOSSER: I don't know. I'm perfectly happy with between 1-1/2 and two percent inflation. What's so bad about that?

BARTIROMO: Exactly.

PLOSSER: I think what's bad about it -- the only thing that's bad about it is the Fed has set a target of two percent. That's -- and, but you know, we can only measure these things so precisely.

The difference between -- I mean, the public doesn't know the difference between 1.8 and two percent inflation.

BARTIROMO: Right, exactly.

PLOSSER: Who cares?

BARTIROMO: Yes, and real quick on trade because there's so much uncertainty. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer expected to meet with the House members to discuss the USMCA.

We know that USMCA is really important. Do you think it passes? Is it going to come to the floor? How does that work its way into the economy, do you think?

PLOSSER: Well, I think that the good thing about that if it passes is that it resolves one more uncertainty out there, and I think that's important. So getting the uncertainty resolved is an important step to sort of re- stabilizing and bringing thing -- calming things down a bit.

BARTIROMO: All right, we will leave it there. Charles, it's great to have you on the program.

PLOSSER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much, Charles Plosser, joining us there.

President Donald Trump just tweeted this morning about today's social media summit and the census. He writes this, "The White House will be hosting a very big and very important social media summit today. Would I have become president without social media? Yes, probably. At its conclusion, we will also go to the beautiful Rose Garden for a news conference on the census and citizenship."

The president is setting off the day this morning and telling us on Twitter.

We'll take a break. When we come back, McDonald's is feeling the heat. The burger chain urged to off its chicken game. Why Chick-fil-A is causing some stress there. Back in a moment with that.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Headlines across America this morning. The American Renews reporting federal judge orders PG&E to respond point by point to newspaper article about safety. The utility knew for years its aging transmission lines could spark fires, but apparently ignored it according to an article in the journal. PG&E now is forced to file "a fresh forthright statement." A utility spokesman says PG&E's most important responsibility is the safety of customers and communities.

The Chicago Tribune this morning writes, McDonald's franchisees are pleading for better chicken sandwich to fend off Chick-fil-A threats. McDonald's feeling the heat from Chick-fil-A franchisees are calling on the Chicago-based burger giant to focus more on chicken so that they can compete better. Chick-fil-A's sales soar last year; flying past rivals. It's now the nation's third largest restaurant chain behind McDonald's and Starbucks.

And then, the Atlanta Journal Constitution this morning writes this: "Drivers begin to return money after $175,000 in cash storm on I-285. It was the scene right out of a Hollywood movie. An armored car door swings open, spills cash all over the busy highway, drivers hit the brakes to grab and go. Police now are asking those who took the money and ran to return it or possibly face charges. What would you do if an armored truck door opens up and all the money starts spilling out?

MCDOWELL: I'd save 50s and 100s. I would be in the middle of the street for some singles.

FREEMAN: Are they really going to charge someone for picking up a 50 off the road? I didn't know that was a crime.

FORBES: Is the IRS going to ask for photos to see, report the income?

BARTIROMO: Yes. Right. I don't think they're going to be able to get that money back.

MCDOWELL: Given how bad drivers are in that state, I don't think -- you better stay in your car. It's dangerous when you're in your automobile, much less standing in the middle of the road.

BARTIROMO: That is funny. All right, have you seen the new Gatorade sports drink, for the first time in years, Gatorade has new sports drink out; what it is and why the brand is standing out? That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Gatorade taking hydration around clock. Bolt 24 -- it is a new, low-calorie, electrolyte-packed drink aimed at athlete, says no artificial sweeteners or flavors. It's part of a new platform for the sport's beverage giant and marks the company's first major product launch in 20 years. Joining us right now is the Senior Vice President of Gatorade, Brett O'Brien. Brett, it's great to have you. Thanks so much for joining us.

BRETT O'BRIEN, SENIOR VICE PRESIDENT, GATORADE: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: And you brought the new Bolt here. Tell us why did you decide to come out with this new product after 20 years?

O'BRIEN: Yes, sure did. This is a really awesome time for Gatorade. It allows us to think about athletes in a whole different way. For years in 1965, Dr. Cade invented Gatorade because he wanted to make athletes better, so that's great. Love it. When you're sweating in your own accord and you're -- or you're in the field of play, you want to drink Gatorade. What happens when you're not in the court? What happens throughout the day as an athlete? How do you best prepare your body and get ready for that moment of participation, for that moment of performance when you've got to be your best? And that's where Bolt plays an amazing role. And we call it Bolt 24, because it's set 24 hours of day of athlete preparation, that's where Bolt comes and really does an amazing job.

MCDOWELL: I'm doing the natural southern shake, might not need that but it is watermelon base which I found really interesting.

O'BRIEN: Yes, it is, and it's totally clean. It's a really interesting way to get -- to get electrolytes. Whereas in the past, electrolytes took different forms especially in salt. Sea salt and watermelon provide the electrolytes on this product.

BARTIROMO: Why are electrolytes so important?

O'BRIEN: It's extremely important for athletes to stay hydrated. So, electrolytes continue to make sure that your body doesn't lose it's -- all of its hydration that's already in your body, and so that salt maintains the hydration that you need.

FORBES: What does it do for us non-athletes?

O'BRIEN: Well, actually, similarly it keeps you hydrated. It's what you want to be able to have in your body, so that you don't get dehydrated and you don't start to feel lethargic and -- but as an athlete, man, how important that is and how important it is to make sure as a coach or as a trainer or as a manager, your athletes, especially young athletes throughout there in the field, and this heat, maintaining proper --

MCDOWELL: 80 calories a bottle, so it's very low calorie for the volume.

O'BRIEN: It is. It's a low calorie, because the proposition is not about that heavy carbohydrate moment, it's about making sure that what you're putting in your body throughout the day is maintaining that level without having to push that -- the energy in the moment of impact, so to speak.

FORBES: Can't wait to show it to my grandchildren.

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: As avowed Red Bull drinker, this is incredibly tasty -- and Red Bull is not for hydration, it's just for --

O'BRIEN: But I like -- thank goodness, you like the taste, that's awesome.

MCDOWELL: It's important though.

O'BRIEN: It's extremely important.

MCDOWELL: -- for the non-athletes.

O'BRIEN: It is. And you know, if you didn't like the taste, it all goes back to the hydration element of --

BARTIROMO: And less sugar, because sugar -- everybody knows has become evil, right?

O'BRIEN: Well, it depends on the functionality, right? Sugar within Gatorade, if you need to be out there participating in heavy weather and putting your best, you need that carbohydrate and energy store to get you going.

BARTIROMO: Brett, thank you. Great to see you.

O'BRIEN: Thank you. Great to be here.

BARTIROMO: Brett O'Brien. Gatorade. Still ahead, Delta earnings out of top of the hour, we'll bring you the number.

urn:contentItem:60MK-ND31-JCMN-Y3SJ-00000-00Fed Economists Finger Monopoly Concentration as Underlying Driver of Neoliberal Economic Restructuring; Barry Lynn in Harpers and Fortnite Lawsuit Put Hot Light on Tech Monopoly Power2020-08-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:49:21ZLexisNexisFed Economists Finger Monopoly Concentration as Underlying Driver of Neoliberal Economic Restructuring; Barry Lynn in Harpers and Fortnite Lawsuit Put Hot Light on Tech Monopoly PowerYves Smith

Aug 19, 2020( Naked Capitalism: http://www.nakedcapitalism.com/ Delivered by Newstex) American policymakers are giving more and more credence to the role of monopoly concentration in the economic restructuring that started in 1980, in the Reagan/Thatcher era, that shifted power and rewards from labor to capital. Importantly, these experts don't just see monopoly as a problem; even basic economic courses show in toy models that they increase prices and decrease output. They also acknowledge that stagnant wages, rising profit share of GDP and escalating wealth concentration are bad outcomes economically and societally. A new paper by Fed economists Isabel Cair ́o and Jae Sim describes how they developed a model to simulate the impact of companies' rising market power[1], in conjunction with the assumption that the owners of capital liked to hold financial assets (here, bonds) as a sign of social status.

They wanted to see it it would explain six developments over the last forty years: Real wage growth stagnating and lagging productivity growth Pre-tax corporate profits rising rapidly relative to GDP Increasing income inequality Increasing wealth inequality Higher household leverage Increased financial instability And it did! For a model to have pretty decent fit for so many variables is not trivial. The first are what the model coughed up, the second, in parenthesis, are the real world data:We've embedded this readable paper at the end of the post. The authors did quite a few sensitivity test and also modeled some alternative explanations, as well as showing panels that compared model outputs over time to real economy outcomes. They also recommend wealth distribution as a way to dampen financial crises, or even just taxing dividends at a healthy level. Bloomberg wrote up the paper[2], an early indicator that it might get traction in official circles, and quoted Matt Stoller: Matt Stoller, the author of 'Goliath: The 100-Year War Between Monopoly Power and Democracy,' said both parties are culpable for the concentration of market power. Change is afoot because lawmakers realize they've ceded too much authority to large companies, he said. 'What you are seeing in the last five years is a shift where lawmakers think democratic institutions should be making more of the decisions,' Stoller said. The anti-monopolists are on a roll. Matt's colleague, the founder and head of Open Markets, Barry Lynn, wrote the cover story in the current Harpers Magazine, The Big Tech Extortion Racket: How Google, Amazon, and Facebook control our lives. [3] I strongly urge you to read the article in full. Lynn describes how America first grappled with monopoly power with the development of railroads and the telegraph. Their answer was regulation: For a century and a half, Americans used common carrier policies to ensure the rule of law in activities that depended on privately held monopolies. These rules served as a pillar of American prosperity through much of the twentieth century. By neutralizing the power of all essential transport and communications systems, the regulations freed Americans to take full advantage of every important network technology introduced during these years, including telephones, water and electrical services, energy pipelines, and even large, logistics-powered retailers. Citizens did not have to worry that the men who controlled the technologies involved would exploit their middleman position to steal other people's business or disrupt balances of power. Lynn explains how this has all gone pear shaped in the Internet era. The tech giants' access to personal information enables them to connect individuals to services they are presumed to like with enough success to drive more and more activity, transactions, and ad revenues through their platforms. Recall that tailoring also allows for price discrimination. Users of Apple devices have been shown higher airline ticket prices than PC/Android customers. Amazon has preyed on third party sellers by copying their goods, as well as demanding more and more of the end sales price. This isn't a new trick. One of my former lawyers, who represented some beauty, cosmetics and dietary supplements entrepreneurs, warned them never to take orders from Walmart. The Bentonville giant would attempt, usually successfully, to place bigger and bigger orders so as to become the little company's biggest customer, by a large margin. Walmart would then squeeze the vendor to lower its price, which had the effect over time of wiping out profits and often leading to business failure. Walmart didn't care. To them, the world is awash in products. But Lynn sees Amazon as more predatory: Back in the day, Walmart's goal was simply to force manufacturers to offer it lower prices in order to undersell and bankrupt rival retailers. Now that Amazon has effectively killed off all its online rivals, its model is to pit every seller and trader on its website against one another in a carefully orchestrated scramble to be placed first before the eyeballs of the busy buyer. Amazon gets to sell both access to the market and protection from its own thuggish behavior. Having said that, it's disappointing to see Lynn demonstrate such a complete misunderstanding of Uber that he includes it as one of his monopoly villains. The fact that Uber has done damage to local taxi companies has zero to do with monopoly power or network effects. Uber's app isn't special and Uber has no cost advantages over traditional cabs; in fact, it is high cost provider. Nor are there meaningful barriers to entry to operating a local transportation business. Uber is a pure and bizarre case of predatory pricing funded by very deep Silicon Valley pockets. Unfortunately, the discussion of Uber suggests an intellectual blindness to the anti-monopolists, that they have such a strong idee fixe that they wind up in 'If the only tool you have is a hammer, then every problem is a nail' mode. A final development, and I must confess to needing to read the court filings to do it justice, is the brazen effort by Apple and now Google to crush games giant Fortnite for trying to go around the app store choke points. 'Tying,' or requiring the buyer of one product (like Apple products) to buy other products (apps only through them) is a per se violation of anti-trust laws. Fortnite would seem to have a very strong case, but Apple has just said it is also cutting Fortnite off from developer tools by August 28. Even big player like Fortnite can't afford to wage this legal war unless it gets an emergency injunction. But this sort of thuggery usually happens less visibly and with companies too small to do anything other than capitulate. If Fortnite can get the courts to restrain Apple and Google while they duke it out in court, expect this to be a very important case. Let's hope Fortnite can afford to proceed. 00 Market Power, Inequality, and Financial Instability - 2020057pap https://www.nakedcapitalism.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/00-Market-Power-Inequality-and-Financial-Instability-2020057pap.pdfhttps://www.nakedcapitalism.com/2020/08/fed-economists-finger-monopoly-concentration-as-underlying-driver-of-neoliberal-economic-restructuring-barry-lynn-in-harpers-and-fortnite-lawsuit-put-hot-light-on-tech-monopoly-power.html?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed:+NakedCapitalism+%28naked+capitalism%29# This entry was posted in Banana republic[4], Economic fundamentals[5], Free markets and their discontents[6], Income disparity[7], Legal[8], Politics[9], Regulations and regulators[10], Technology and innovation[11], The destruction of the middle class[12], The dismal science[13] on August 19, 2020[14] by Yves Smith[15].
